body.p: People have often wondered what kind of performance improvement Gentoo Linux provides over other Linux distributions. This section is intended to help answer that question in a tangible way.

section.title: HispaLinux 2003: Gentoo Linux 1.4 vs. Mandrake 9.1 load-times

body.p: On 23 Sep 2003, Jose Alberto Suarez Lopez gave a presentation at HispaLinux 2003 where he demonstrated the load-time performance of the official Gentoo Linux 1.4 release. To compare load-time performance, he used Mandrake 9.1. Mandrake 9.1 ships with its binaries "pre-linked," which allows for faster load-times. In contrast, Gentoo Linux ships without pre-linked binaries by default.

These benchmarks compare Mandrake 9.1 against Gentoo Linux 1.4 in both a un-prelinked (default) and pre-linked state. Prelinking was performed as per the steps of the Gentoo Prelinking Guide. Only the applications being tested were pre-linked, not the entire system as is Mandrake 9.1.

Here is an overview of the operating systems benchmarked for the load-time test:
Mandrake 9.1 (with prelink enabled by default, default kernel)
Gentoo Linux 1.4 for Pentium III (official prebuilt "GRP" packages from CD, no prelink, gaming-sources-2.4.20-r3)
Gentoo Linux 1.4 for Pentium III (official prebuilt "GRP" packages from CD, with prelink, gaming-sources-2.4.20-r3)

Here is an overview of the system used for the load-time test:
Pentium III Coppermine 733Mhz
128MB RAM
1461 BogoMIPS (not an authoritative performance measure but people seem to like to know this :)
To perform the test, three applications (Mozilla, NetBeans and Kmail) were repeatedly loaded. Initial load speed as well as subsequent load speed was recorded.

body.note: In these tests, the first column lists initial load time. The second and third columns list the time required to load the application the second and third time respectively.

p.b: Test 1: Mandrake 9.1 with prelink enabled by default
Test 2: Gentoo Linux 1.4 for Pentium III without prelink
Test 3: Gentoo Linux 1.4 for Pentium III with prelink
p.note: The NetBeans test was not performed for Test 3 since NetBeans itself is not prelinkable. Also, only the tested applications (rather than the entire system) were prelinked. Prelinking the entire system should not negatively impact these performance numbers, and could theoretically improve them.

body.p: Here are the conclusions of the load-time test:

ul.li: Mozilla loads nearly twice as fast under Gentoo Linux 1.4 for Pentium III (both initial and subsequent loads)
Initial load time for NetBeans under Gentoo is over twice as fast as on Mandrake 9.1
Subsequent load time for NetBeans seems about even for both Gentoo and Mandrake

li.b: Gentoo Linux 1.4 with prelink loads Kmail over 10 times faster than Gentoo Linux without prelink or Mandrake 9.1 with prelink

body.p: What can be gleaned from these results? For one, the default optimizations of Gentoo Linux 1.4 for Pentium III appear to make a very significant difference in "real world" application load-time performance. Binary applications like NetBeans do not benefit as much from this performance improvement, although initial load-time for binary applications does seem to be a lot better under Gentoo Linux.

In addition, KDE C++ applications like Kmail seem to show a huge load-time peformance improvement -- over 10 times faster than Mandrake 9.1 and Gentoo 1.4 without prelink -- when prelinked. Prelinking seems to be very beneficial for improving load-time performance for KDE apps, although Mozilla shows negligible improvement. Could this be due to Mozilla's internal architecture which prevents it from being able to benefit significantly from being pre-linked? Or did our tester mistakenly try to prelink /usr/bin/mozilla instead of of /usr/lib/mozilla/mozilla-bin? Only time (and another load-time performance test) will tell! :)

Gentoo Linux is able to generallyl deliver better overall performance than other Linux distributions for a couple of reasons. First and most important, we try our best to offer the latest and best free software technologies to our users, including the latest compiler toolchains. Newer compilers produce faster code, so by getting these tools into your hands sooner, Gentoo is able to give you better performance. It's important to understand that there is no magic involved except getting the latest free software improvements to you in a timely manner.

Here's the second way we improve the performance of Gentoo. The official Gentoo Linux 1.4 release ships with pre-built binary packages that have been optimized for specific CPU models. For example, in this test, Gentoo Linux for Pentium III was used, which runs very fast on Pentium III and higher processors, but will not run on Pentium II or "lower" processors. By providing tailored builds for each CPU model, we are able to use the full instruction set of your CPU and deliver the best possible system performance to you. For x86 systems, we currently offer 1.4 builds for "x86" (generic PC), "i686" (Pentium Pro and higher), Pentium III, Pentium 4 and Athlon XP systems. In addition, users who wish to "build from scratch" can optimize Gentoo Linux as they desire.

If you'd like to purchase Gentoo Linux, please visit The Gentoo Store. The official x86 1.4 release contains a number of official builds and pre-built packages, all optimized to provide excellent performance and stability.
